channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: 5 keys to project success on GitHub
item.description: Michael Glukhovsky, co-founder of RethinkDB, shares his tips for how to make your project successful on GitHub. In his words, "it's all about engaging the community".

item.title: 10 golden rules for becoming a better programmer
item.description: Paul Seal's tips on being a better programmer. What would you add to his list?

item.title: Kill Your Dependencies
item.description: Mike Perham urges Ruby developers to look to their dependencies, and trim them down to only those really needed. As he notes, this is an issue for all programming languages.

item.title: How To Grow a Development Team ... Hotel California Style!
item.description: Andrew shares his tips for minimising churn while growing a development team.

item.title: Grant Proposal: RPerl User Documentation, Part 2
item.description: Will Braswell has applied for a second grant: $1600 to continue work on the Learning RPerl user tutorial. Add your comments if you agree or disagree with this proposal being funded.

item.title: Text, Grammar, Tree - the 3
item.description: Yary had been thinking about writing a reversible grammar, so you could feed it a parse tree and it would generate the original text (that had produced the parse tree). Raiph pointed out in the comments that Jonathan Worthington has a proof of concept already.

item.title: Announce: Mac OS X Installer for release 2016.01
item.description: A MacOSX installer for the latest Perl 6 Rakudo star release is now available.

item.title: Perl6 module namespace
item.description: Enkidu bemoans the fact that lots of Perl 6 modules are being created with top-level names, such as Chess, and not being put in appropriate namespaces, such as Games::Chess.

item.title: From Regular Expressions to Grammars: Pt. 2
item.description: Jeff continues his series on Perl 6 regular expressions and grammars, which has so far been about the former.

item.title: A few words on Perl 6 versioning and compatibility
item.description: Jonathan outlines his Perl 6 will be versioned, including the language definition, the Rakudo compiler, and MoarVM.

item.title: Credit the first or last uploader on meta::cpan?
item.description: This was Helmut's response to Rik's post. He thinks that everyone with upload permissions should be displayed, which is slightly different from my proposal.

item.title: It takes a community to raise a CPAN module
item.description: This was my response to Rik's post. I think that rather than show just one person, we should show everyone who's done a release, in the order of whose released most recently.

item.title: the "credit the last uploader" problem
item.description: When you look at a module or dist on MetaCPAN or search.cpan.org, they both show the last person who released it. Rik points out that this isn't always the most appropriate person to show, and suggests that the owner of the distribution should be displayed. He also opened a github issue for MetaCPAN, specifically about highlighting when a module has ADOPTME, HANDOFF, or NEEDHELP.

item.title: Perl-HowTo.de moved to GitHub Pages
item.description: I can't really tell you much beyond the title, because it's written in German.

item.title: Use Path::Tiny instead of home-made ReadFile and WriteFile
item.description: When refactoring tests for a module, Gabor noticed functions for reading and writing files. He shows how you can use Path::Tiny for this, and also mentions File::Slurper, which is my go-to module for those tasks these days.

item.title: Run Perl::Tidy to beautify the code
item.description: Gabor shows how you can use Perl::Tidy to ensure your code always followings your layout preferences, even if some of it was written by someone else.

item.title: Windows DLL Relocation and Perl
item.description: Andy describes a bug found in the way Perl builds DLL files on Windows when compiling with GCC, and how it was fixed.

item.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: February 2nd-7th
item.description: As Chester discovers his son Danny has been sleeping with Annie and everyone awaits the kidnappers' demands for Jessica's release, the governor urges Burt to disassociate himself from his family.

item.title: Simplest way of serving local files over HTTP?
item.description: Alex wondered what's the easiest way to serve up files using a Perl 5 module? Several people have chipped in so far in the comments, but I'm sure more of you won't be able to resist.

item.title: Programming Quadcopters, Part I
item.description: A video of Timm's talk to Madison Perl Mongers about programming quadcopters in Perl.

item.title: Test your Git wrapper against 500 versions of Git
item.description: Philippe takes us through all the different versions of Git that he's tested Git::Repository against, and shares the scripts he's written to help with that.

item.title: Using lcpan to index your DarkPAN
item.description: Perlancar describes the lcpan tool, which you can use to manage your own CPAN mirror. There's going to be a series of daily tips on lcpan usage: here's the first.

item.title: What's new on CPAN - January 2015
item.description: David's selection of new modules released to CPAN in January. He's decided not to continue with his "module of the month", considering it an experiment that has run its course. One worth looking at is Importer.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: YAPC::NA::2016 Call for Master Classes
item.description: YAPC::NA are looking for people to give master classes before and after this year's YAPC::NA.

item.title: YAPC::NA::2016 Call for Speakers
item.description: The YAPC::NA::2016 call for speakers is now open! There must be something you could talk about: Perl 5, Perl 6, the transition between the two (either way!), some other programming language, or some other topic you think may be of interest to programmers.

item.title: Announcing the Perl QA Hackathon 2016
item.description: The announcement for this year's QA Hackathon, which is being held in Rugby (in the UK), from Thursday 21st April through Sunday 24th April.

item.title: #238 - The QA Hackathon is looking for sponsorship
item.description:
The Perl QA Hackathon brings together the lead developers for the Perl toolchain. It's going to be in the UK this year. It's funded through sponsorship, so why not see if your employer can support it. Every little helps!

How do you think authors and related users should be acknowledged when looking at modules on MetaCPAN? This topic generated a fair bit of discussion this week.

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
